I'm really surprised that more people who talk about this case, don't realize/mention that covering mirrors in the home and closing curtains are all funerary customs. Mirrors were covered to keep the spirit of the deceased from being trapped in the mirror and the curtains were closed to symbolically show that the soul has left.

Also, the covering of the mirrors in the home suggests that the killer was oddly being respectful of the souls. Throughout History, it is known that people liked to cover mirrors as a religious belief that souls may be inadvertently trapped if the mirrors weren't covered up when a death occured. They also had a tendency to stop clocks at the time of death.

I'll toss my hat in the ring of ideas. The closing of the windows and covering the mirrors with cloth was a popular mourning tradition in the Victorian era, (ending in 1901) and Edwardian era (ending in 1910) so the idea of these funerary practices being performed is a possibility. It would also be very odd for the murderer to have killed them, moved their bodies / covering them, then gone around the house closing blinds and covering windows and, according to some sources, eaten a meal. A strange amount of interaction between the criminal and the crime scene without something being stolen.

As much as it has been sort of made a clichÃ© by movies and TV, there is something of a tradition from a long time ago, about covering mirrors in the instance of a deceased person so that they can pass on peacefully. I'm kinda surprised no one's mentioned this but in the Victorian era, it was common practice to draw the curtains and cover the bodies after death. They would also cover mirrors to prevent spirits from being "trapped in the looking glass". They murders were only a decade after Victoria died, so the practices were likely still common, even in America. If anything, it sounds like the murderer did these funerary practices to prevent the spirits from coming after them.

It's so annoying when ppl act like your arrogant because you prescribe to proven scientific and psychological phenomenal and not ghosts ğŸ™ƒ  It's called Pareidolia. It is a common human tendency to try to make sense of the nonsensical. Especially when your literally using inductive logic to prove ghosts exist. It's the same logic behind seeing faces in toast just with noise. The "voice" is a natural sound our brains rewire into one thing or another that makes sense to us like "yanny" or "laurel". Like "what else could it be" is just lazy. Especially when it is a recognized physiological phenomena.

Lol i realized this a month late for the postmortem, but there is a grieving tradition of covering mirrors. It was typically done to all the mirrors in a house when someone passes; IIRC it stems from a belief that the spirit could be trapped in a mirror and not pass on. It could have been the murderer in an weird act of mercy; it also could have been a towns person who was touring the house in the 3 hours till the scene was secured

fun fact: when a murderer covers the face of their victims it usually means they know who they are on a personal level. This is addressed to everyone here who ascribes any technological efficacy or functional legitimacy to the so-called "spirit boxes". I suspect that the marketers of these devices correctly presuppose that people will only employ them when in a reputedly haunted place which would ostensibly be suitable and conducive to purposes of receiving communications or transmissions from ghostly phenomena. If you want to test the absurdity of the hypothesis that such devices confirm the existence of the paranormal than just activate it while at Walmart or some other obviously banal place that has no infamous reputation and I can almost guarantee that you will encounter the same sort of transmissions, or whatever you want to call the noise emissions from this device that you would, had you been in some allegedly haunted place. And I will also add that ghosts and the entire edifice of the supernatural are merely a byproduct of the fallibility, credulity and pervasive stupidity of most human beings who lack the capacity to properly discern the true causes of that which they misconstrue as validating their absurdist phantasies.
I wouldn't tell the spirits that you are there to help them because in all reality you're just there to see if they exist. So be honest about it with them, you may get better responses. Don't offer help if it isn't the truth.

This case has all the hallmarks of the "man from the train" killer. If you've never heard that theory I'd highly suggest looking it up but the short version is that a vagrant serial killer traveled from town to town by train working oddjobs and occasionally murdering random families. He targeted large families, usually with young girls, snuck into their house while they were out and waited until they went to sleep before murdering them all, typically with a blunt or sharp impliment taken from around the house. He would then cover all the windows/mirrors, eat some of their food and slip out before the next morning.

Highly recommend the book the man on the train, which discusses how this murder is likely linked to a serial killer using the railroad to travel. Many things in this case match other cases he is believed to have committed.
05:00 Lena had been handled by the killer after her death. The blood on her arm was from the killer and not due to a cut. No victim had been attacked below the neck. 13:24 Joe wasn't hit with the blade of the axe. Sara, his wife, was. Joe was hit only with the blunt side of the axe, like all the other victims. 15:52 No. There may have been cookies on the table or uncleared dishes but there was no evidence the killer made themselves a meal. 21:17 No one really knows how the killer might have gained entry. This "removed screen" guess comes from another, likely related, axe murder in Paola, KS several days before. The killer removed a screen to get in through the window. In this case, there was clear evidence. Not in Villisca. There was no indoor plumbing though, so the back door might have been unlocked. 21:33 It was impossible. The absolute biggest "wrong" thing said about this crime. The entry into the attic space is in the parent's bedroom closet, which, in 1912, was crammed with clothes and boxes. The killer couldn't have hid there without removing all the boxes, then somehow replacing them, then crashing through the boxes into the bedroom later. Also, contemporary investigators looked into this at the time and saw nothing but undisturbed dust in the attic. There was no sign of anyone having been in there for a LONG time.

I did a course in criminal psychology and there is a lot of things that does not make sense in this case but what stands out the most to me is: Covering up the victims is a classic move done by killers who knew them personally and/or instantly regretted it after doing it. Very common in crimes of passion. The fact he entered and exited the house easily also adds to the fact that the family probably knew the murderer. Also adds to the things heard in the spirit box like "Stop me" and "I'm miserable". I don't think who did this was the "murder is fun" kind of person. If I had to guess: a very troubled man who was in love or had an affair with the wife - it would explain why the husband was killed in a more violent manner when compared to the others.

For postmortem: On the topic of the killer covering all of the faces, mirrors, and windows, covering mirrors after death was also a common tradition around the time to prevent spirits from getting trapped in them. It was almost like the murderer was mimicking the rituals of a family member, respecting them enough to try and ease their soulsâ€™ passage into Heaven. So in addition to the killer being ashamed, the mirror thing could also suggest that the family was murdered by someone who knew them personally (or maybe they were just afraid of the spirits coming back for revenge).

I wonder if most of the furnishings in there are original to the family, or replicas.  Most museum houses don't have the authentic furniture and items that belonged to the family there, because the house was never initially intended to be a museum.  Later on, when the house is declared a historical site, replicas are brought in to try and get as close as possible.  The Molly Brown house in Denver is like that,   most of the stuff is a replica, not her actual things.  They didn't have Barbie in 1912, so no way those toys belongs to the kids killed there.  There were probably people who lived there for several decades before some historical society, or the city, decided to turn it into a tourist attraction.

for the #postmortem, not so much a question as a possible answer for covering the mirrors. I've heard of a tradition that covers mirrors after a death in the house so the spirit doesn't get trapped in it, and this is an old tradition that some cultures still practice to this day. So this would suggest that the killer cared about their victims afterlife to some degree, whether to allow them to go to heaven or to prevent getting haunted by the victims.

I don't know if it was mentioned, but it was tradition to cover mirrors with a cloth when a death occurred in a household. There was a belief that if the mirror was uncovered, the spirit would get trapped in the mirror and not be able to pass on to the afterlife. This also worked if the mirror was turned against the wall.

For #postmortem : I'm not sure if it's a global thing, but here in the UK around the same era and a bit earlier it was customary to cover a mirror (and sometimes other reflective surfaces like windows) to ensure that the deceased persons spirit did not become trapped in the mirror. This was particularly big in the Victorian era. Could this be the reason that the mirrors were covered? Therefore could the ax wielding maniac be a Boogara?

Alot of the things that the killer did like covering their faces and the mirrors showed remorse or guilt. Usually covering the face of the victim is because the killer cannot stand to look at what they did or even as a way to put them to rest. For #postmortem: I hate to cut the police any slack, but at this time, fingerprints weren't widely used as evidence by American law enforcement. That's especially true in a small town. U.S. officials were still betting on bodily measurements being the primary way to ID suspects. That's likely why the town marshall didn't didn't see the fingerprints on the ax as necessary evidence.

covering mirrors, covering the victims with sheets and clothing, and closing the drapes all relate to old funeral customs. specifically people used to cover mirrors after a death in a house because it was said that the spirit of the deceased would continue to wander around for three days after, and could become trapped the mirror if they saw their own reflection. closing the curtains was also a common practice after a death in a house/during a wake. for whatever reason it sounds like the killer arranged the house and victims as you would to prepare for their funerals.

For the postmortem: Covering mirrors use to be a common practice in the olden days when there was a dying person, or death in a home. It was believed that doing so would prevent the spirit from becoming trapped in the mirror. That being said, itâ€™s certainly odd for a murderer to show that sort of respect for their victims. Given that the father had the most brutal demise I suspect he was the true target. The rest of the family were collateral damage, metaphorical lambs(or pigs) to the slaughter. Perhaps thatâ€™s why they left behind the bacon.

9:28 â€œghosts are realâ€  *Shane screaming in anguish*
Regarding the covered mirrors, back in the olden days some cultures believed that when you passed away your spirit could get trapped inside the mirrors so families would cover them and stop clocks at the exact moment of death too. But what the families of the departed would ALSO do was open the windows to 'set the spirit' free so if a murderer is covering the mirrors and not opening the windows then maybe he wished for all their spirits to remain trapped inside the house... Idk. Maybe he did open up the -or- A window. Since 2000 people trampled through the evidence, God knows what the hell truly happened after the murders. But the covered Windows are a very old religious/cultural custom that still happen in some homes in the South when someone dies. Just fyi...
My great-great grandparents were a murder-suicide in 1911. The scene was raided by neighbors immediately after the incident.  They toured the house like they were at a museum.  It got so crowded that the police started beating people with clubs to get them out so the coroner could get to the bodies and the morge could take them away. We found articles about it in the St. Louis Post Dispatch and the Globe Democrat.
I know I'm late to this comment section, but I think it is worth  mentioning and pointing out that there seem to be some similarities between the Villisca axe murders and S1E2 Unsolved True Crime 'The Terrifying Axeman of New Orleans'. Maybe this is a stretch, but for both crimes all the victims were asleep in bed, nothing was stolen, and the axe (weapon) belonged to the victim.  New Orleans is directly south only a few states away and the killings occured 6 years after the murders in Iowa. Another weird thing I noticed in the New Orleans case the killer said "I am invisible" in a letter he wrote to the police. When Ryan was investigating he got audio that was recorded "I am miserable" but at the time I watched this episode I thought I heard "I am invisible" (just a weird connection I made). I think it would be worth taking a look at other axe murders that occured between 1913 and 1918 heading south from Iowa to New Orleans.

For #postmortem: The Villisca Ax Murderer is actually most likely an uncaught serial killer. A few years prior to Villisca there was an ax murderer killing families along the train line from california to texas, it went on for years and he was never caught, and one day he just seemingly stopped for no reason. That was until a few years later when the ax murders picked up again in small towns in the midwest. Both murder sprees have similarities like the killer using the victim's own ax and sticking around after the murder and making a meal in the kitchen.

Hmm, it might be a bit obvious, but this definitely sounds like it was personal... If this was the only killing like this, then it seems likely that it was targeted. It almost seems like the killer had a personal grudge against specifically the one who was killed with the sharp end of the axe.  He covered up the mirror because he was ashamed of looking at himself. The bacon was most likely a message of sorts, what it meant, who knows.  The killer felt comfortable in the house even after he committed the crime, he made himself a meal after he killed, not something most people would do, it was probably in that moment where the killer got the bacon and took it back upstairs. I suspect it was someone the family trusted, I think the killer knew the layout of the house, and even how the floor made noises, honestly, I think it was a family member who did it, most likely on the side of the parent who wasn't "axed a sharp question", they killed their family members and was ashamed of it, hence covering up the mirror. 6 kids is a lot, and maybe someone in the family felt angered by this, wrapping up bacon in a cloth is a weird message, unless the main message is the cloth, maybe it was trying to mimic a baby after being born and then wrapped up in a cloth. #postmortem About sheet over the mirror. There is an old slavic tradition (maybe not only slavic idk I am telling it because I am a slavic myself). People cover all mirrors in the house during funerals or right after someone dies in the house. It is believed that the soul can be trapped inside the mirrors.

For some context on the covered mirror, it's a documented thing that very mentally ill people when experiencing an episode will cover mirrors. From what I know it's because they either don't recognise themselves, or they're too ashamed too see themselves but it could be for many other reasons. Hope this helps anyone confused by that :)

do they know that sheets over mirrors is very much a superstition  from olden times - when a death takes place in the home, the mirrors are covered and a window is opened because people believed that ghosts could get trapped in the mirrors, like they would get lost on their way to the after life hence the mirrors were covered and a window opened so the spirit of the deceased could safely leave.

Creepiest spirit box yet
Regarding the covered mirrors and windows, these murders happened in 1912 so the murderer would most likely have been raised with Victorian Era death superstitions (that are seen across many cultures with significance of rituals varying slightly). Mirrors were covered in the house of the deceased (and definitely room where death occurred) to prevent the deceasedâ€™s spirit from being trapped. It was also believed one should open the window in a deceased persons room so their soul can escape, (this one am pulling from â€œAlias Graceâ€ by Margaret Atwood but has credence in superstitious rituals post death).   General summation of beliefs from communities that cover mirrors after death  are that ghosts could carry away souls through mirrors and never rest. Another is that people believed the deceased could harm the living by entering the physical world through a mirror.Â Finally some cover as its to keep thoughts present while mourning and looking at ones appearance during this time is considered vain.

Yâ€™all were mentioning some thing about the mirrors being covered. There are some people especially in that day and age that would cover mirrors when people passed away because there was a Superstition or A belief that a spirit could get trapped in mirrors. So they would cover a mirror when they knew someone was about to pass away or as the person was passing away. A lot of times they would also stop the clocks in the room because it was documenting the time of the passing. But Iâ€™m just mentioning this because this was another tradition or whatever that they would do when someone passed away but it also causing a lot of weird superstitions because people would say that it mustâ€™ve been the spirit to stop the clockâ€¦ But it was actually someone who stopped the clock to document the time of passing.  Also you mentioned some thing about the victims having their faces covered with clothing or blankets. Usually when someone does this itâ€™s out of remorse or because they knew the person and they had shame in what they did. So Iâ€™m thinking it was a high possibility that the person who did this knew the victims. Fake as fook
it's probably been mentioned elsewhere, but mirrors and windows have spiritual significance in many cultures.  You open a window to let the soul out after someone dies/let their ancestors come to take them away.  Mirrors are also considered spiritual portals and depending on the religion or culture, they're covered after a death (or just in general) to keep souls or spirits from entering the place or, alternately, to keep them from leaving the place.  Along those lines, doors were also left unlocked so a spirit can pass on, and buddy said NOPE to that as well.  Though it may not have been reflective (NOT an intentional pun) of the Moore's faith --the wiki said they were at a Presbyterian church that night-- it could be the killer was intentionally trying to keep the spirits of these people from passing on, even if just symbolically based on his/her own beliefs... which is spiteful AF.  No clue about the bacon.  The covering of the faces could be seen as a sign of respect, though it was mostly likely out of superstition, with eyes also being believed to be portals and even the belief that the soul escapes through the mouth.
Good old parlor tricks

For #postmortem: based on all of the audio recording you got from the house, what story did you put together about the house? Because the story I put together is kinda sad.    In case you want to know my story: an individual, possibly with some sort of mental illness like schizophrenia or DID, came into the home and killed these people. Once he came to, he realized what he did and felt shame and guilt. This explains the cloth on the victims faces and the mirrors (in some cultures, when there is a death, the person will put fabric on mirrors to keep their souls in the afterlife).  Ps, I am not excusing the actions of this person that killed this family and blaming it on mental illness, but it does make me sad

i think the interesting thing about the "what is it?" recording, other than the fact that it was clear and could be heard even without subtitles (i was listening to just the audio at the time), was the fact that it sounded like a whisper instead of a tone that one would use in news or announcements on the radio. this for announcements sort of voice was the "anthony" recording from the viper room, which was the only other clear voice i heard that made sense even without subtitles. but that one sounded like it could be from a sports announcement or smth, as if someone announcing a player's name and the spirit box wasn't working correctly hence the three syllables. also asking "what is it?" in a hushed voice doesn't rlly make sense to me on a radio news channel or something, unless it was like an interview and they're doing something that prompted the said question. this isn't enough to make me believe especially since the spirit box is something that could be baloney and/or wasn't working correctly, but i think it's interesting to compare what is probs two of the clearest spirit box voices from the show.

Honestly the idea that the murderers spirit is in the house seems absurd to me. Usually it's the victims who stay in their place of death, but killers don't reside in their victim's houses unless they died there or spent a majority of their time there.
